explanation: The report is correct. In OS_TranslatePath the code does VirtPathLen = OS_strnlen(VirtualPath, OS_MAX_PATH_LEN) and finds name_ptr = strrchr(VirtualPath,'/') + 1, but then calls memchr(name_ptr, 0, OS_MAX_FILE_NAME). Nothing in the code bounds the memchr length argument to the actual remaining bytes available in the VirtualPath object (i.e. VirtPathLen - (name_ptr - VirtualPath) + 1). If OS_MAX_FILE_NAME is larger than the remaining bytes after name_ptr, memchr will read up to OS_MAX_FILE_NAME bytes starting at name_ptr and thus can access memory beyond the VirtualPath object. The provided counterexample (VirtualPath = "/a" with a large OS_MAX_FILE_NAME) demonstrates this. That is a potential out-of-bounds access of a string.h function and therefore violates MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17. A safe fix is to limit the memchr length to the remaining string/buffer length (for example compute the remaining length from VirtPathLen and use that or use OS_strnlen(name_ptr, remaining_limit)).
